### 255. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.

### 260. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.

### 162. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.

### 70. How much does an experimentation platform cost?

**Date:** 2024-09-10T00:00-07:00  
**Author:** Sedona Duggal  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/how-much-does-an-experimentation-platform-cost


**Summary:**  
Comparing pricing across experimentation platforms can be tricky, with different pricing structures and usage tiers to decipher. To simplify this process, we made a detailed pricing model that breaks down costs across the most popular experimentation platforms, complete with all our assumptions and calculations. The bottom line: Statsig is the most cost-effective and scalable option out there


**Key Points:**

- Comparing pricing across experimentation platforms can be tricky, with different pricing structures and usage tiers to decipher.

- Experimentation platforms use different usage metrics to price their platforms, making it difficult to compare pricing models.

**Summary:**  
We‚Äôre excited to announce the release of stratified sampling on Statsig. Stratified samplingallows you to avoid pre-existing differences between groups in your experiments along metrics or the distribution of users across arbitrary attributes. For B2B tests, or tests where a tail-end of power users drive a large portion of an overall metric value, this feature meaningfully reduces both false positive rates and false discovery rates, making your results more consistent and trustworthy

### 161. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.

### 208. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.

### 98. Top 8 common experimentation mistakes and how to fix them

**Key Points:**

- Data integrity:Ensure that your allocation point is consistent and verify your distributions using chi-squared tests to detect sample ratio mismatches.

- Skepticism and Vigilance:Regularly check data integrity over different segments and time periods to identify inconsistencies early.

- Proper Metrics:Collaborate with data science teams to ensure metrics are correctly defined and measured, focusing on meaningful business-driven KPIs.

- Statistical Methods:Use t-tests for means and z-tests for proportions in most cases. Ensure your statistical tests are relevant to your hypotheses.

### 179. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.

- bits is enough to cover Rodrigo‚Äôs projected lifespan in milliseconds.

- bits is about the # of RUIDs that can be generated single threaded in Rodrigo‚Äôs personal computer (~20M ids per second).

### 133. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.

### 158. RUID‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäTime-Travel-Safe, Distributed, Unique, 64 bit ids generated in Rust

**Summary:**  
RUID‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäTime-Travel-Safe, Distributed, Unique, 64 bit ids generated in¬†Rust
RUIDs (Rodrigo‚Äôs Unique Identifiers) are 64 bit ids mathematically guaranteed to be unique when generated within the sameRUID root. Check it out on¬†GitHub. AnRUID rootis a set of RUID generators where each generator can be uniquely identified through shared configuration


**Key Points:**

- RUID‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäTime-Travel-Safe, Distributed, Unique, 64 bit ids generated in¬†Rust

- The canonical version of RUIDs (this repo) uses 41 bits for timestamp, 14 bits for a monotonically increasing sequence, and 9 bits for the root¬†id.

- bits is enough to cover Rodrigo‚Äôs projected lifespan in milliseconds.

- bits is about the # of RUIDs that can be generated single threaded in Rodrigo‚Äôs personal computer (~20M ids per second).

- bits is what remains after the calculations above, and is used for root id. The root id is further split into 5 bits for a cluster id, and 4 bits for a node¬†id.

### 251. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.

### 126. Top 8 common experimentation mistakes and how to fix them

I've summarized the discussion and outlined the 8 common experimentation mistakes and how to fix them


**Key Points:**

- Data integrity:Ensure that your allocation point is consistent and verify your distributions using chi-squared tests to detect sample ratio mismatches.

- See our blog onSample Ratio Mismatch

- Skepticism and Vigilance:Regularly check data integrity over different segments and time periods to identify inconsistencies early.

- Proper Metrics:Collaborate with data science teams to ensure metrics are correctly defined and measured, focusing on meaningful business-driven KPIs.

- Statistical Methods:Use t-tests for means and z-tests for proportions in most cases. Ensure your statistical tests are relevant to your hypotheses.

### 241. Don‚Äôt be a Holdout holdout

**Date:** 2022-05-04T21:22:13.000Z  
**Author:** Vineeth Madhusudanan  
**URL:** https://statsig.com/blog/getting-in-on-holdouts


**Summary:**  
An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts
Feature Level¬†Holdouts
Good teams move fast. They‚Äôre trying several ideas at any given time. When they find something that works, they ship it and find the next idea to try


**Key Points:**

- An opinionated guide on using¬†Holdouts

- Engineering overhead. For each feature you ship with a holdout, you‚Äôre committing to support an if-then-else fork in your code. For a fast moving team, having to support multiple code paths makes the test and debug matrix large. Shorter holdouts help make this manageable. When your legacy code path breaks‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you don‚Äôt find and fix it swiftly, your holdout results become untrustworthy.

- Opportunity cost. When you ship features that increase revenue or retention, a large holdout means leaving those gains on the table. There‚Äôs also dissatisfaction you cause when someone sees a friend with a shiny new feature that they don‚Äôt¬†have.

- Monitoring. Holdouts are typically analyzed in detail only at the end of the holdout period. It‚Äôs useful to check in on them at a regular cadence (e.g. monthly) to make sure there isn‚Äôt anything unexpected that may taint the holdout. A broken control variant impacting only 1% of your users can make the Holdout useless if you only detect it at the end of the holdout period. There‚Äôs little point comparing metrics between users with new features and users with a broken experience. The act of checking the performance of the Holdout group can spawn investigations to understand unexpected movements.

- Users, Customer Support & Marketing.For people in the holdout, it is confusing to see friends get a spiffy new feature, while you don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to retire and create new holdouts every cycle‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso it‚Äôs not the same set of users punished again and¬†again.
